abstract: A type that converts a given data type into a representation in another type, such as a string.

codeExamples.code:
let style = IntegerFormatStyle<Int>()
    .rounded(rule: .down, increment: 1000)
    .locale(Locale(identifier: "fr_FR"))
let rounded = 123456789.formatted(style) // "123 456 000"

declaration.code: protocol FormatStyle<FormatInput, FormatOutput> : Decodable, Encodable, Hashable

overview:
## Overview

Types conforming to the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] protocol take their input type and produce formatted instances of their output type. The formatting process accounts for locale-specific conventions, like grouping and separators for numbers, and presentation of units for measurements. The format styles Foundation provides produce their output as [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/String] or [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/AttributedString] instances. You can also create custom styles that format their output as any type, like XML or JSON [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Data] or an image.

There are two basic approaches to using a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle]:

Foundation provides format styles for integers ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle]), floating-point numbers ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FloatingPointFormatStyle]), decimals ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal/FormatStyle]), measurements ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Measurement/FormatStyle]), arrays ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ListFormatStyle]), and more. The “Conforming types” section below shows all the format styles available from Foundation and any system frameworks that implement the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] protocol. The numeric format styles also provide supporting format styles to format currency and percent values, like [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle/Currency] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal/FormatStyle/Percent].

### Modifying a format style

Format styles include modifier methods that return a new format style with an adjusted behavior. The following example creates an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle], then applies modifiers to round values down to the nearest 1,000 and applies formatting appropriate to the `fr_FR` locale:

Foundation caches identical instances of a customized format style, so you don’t need to pass format style instances around unrelated parts of your app’s source code.

### Accessing static instances

Types that conform to [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] typically extend the base protocol with type properties or type methods to provide convenience instances. These are available for use in a data type’s `formatted(_:)` method when the format style’s input type matches the data type. For example, the various numeric format styles define `number` properties with generic constraints to match the different numeric types ([doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Double], [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int], [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Float16], and so on).

To see how this works, consider this example of a default formatter for an [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int] value. Because `123456789` is a [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger], its [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger/formatted(_:)-4qd73] method accepts an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] parameter. The following example shows the style’s default behavior in the `en_US` locale.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] extends [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] with multiple type properties called `number`, each of which is an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] instance; these properties differ by which [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger]-conforming type they take as input. Since one of these statically-defined properties ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle/number-7fxvo]) takes [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int] as its input, you can use this type property instead of instantiating a new format style instance. Using dot notation to access this property on the inferred [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] makes the call point much easier to read, as seen here:

Furthermore, since you can customize these statically-accessed format style instances, you can rewrite the example from the previous section without instantiating a new [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle], like this:

### Parsing with a format style

To perform the opposite conversion — from formatted output type to input data type — some format styles provide a corresponding [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ParseStrategy] type. These format styles typically expose an instance of this type as a variable, called `parseStrategy`.

You can use a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ParseStrategy] one of two ways:
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/formatstyle
crawled: 2025-12-02T18:07:18Z
---

# FormatStyle

**Protocol**

A type that converts a given data type into a representation in another type, such as a string.

## Declaration

```swift
protocol FormatStyle<FormatInput, FormatOutput> : Decodable, Encodable, Hashable
```

## Overview

Types conforming to the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] protocol take their input type and produce formatted instances of their output type. The formatting process accounts for locale-specific conventions, like grouping and separators for numbers, and presentation of units for measurements. The format styles Foundation provides produce their output as [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/String] or [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/AttributedString] instances. You can also create custom styles that format their output as any type, like XML or JSON [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Data] or an image.

There are two basic approaches to using a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle]:

- Create an instance of a type that conforms to [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] and apply it to one or more instances of the input type, by calling the style’s [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle/format(_:)] method. Use this when you want to customize a style once and apply it repeatedly to many instances.
- Pass an instance of a type that conforms to [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] to the data type’s `formatted(_:)` method, which takes the style as a parameter. Use this for one-off formatting scenarios, or when you want to apply different format styles to the same data value. For the simplest cases, most types that support formatting also have a no-argument `formatted()` method that applies a locale-appropriate default format style.

Foundation provides format styles for integers ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle]), floating-point numbers ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FloatingPointFormatStyle]), decimals ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal/FormatStyle]), measurements ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Measurement/FormatStyle]), arrays ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ListFormatStyle]), and more. The “Conforming types” section below shows all the format styles available from Foundation and any system frameworks that implement the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] protocol. The numeric format styles also provide supporting format styles to format currency and percent values, like [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle/Currency] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal/FormatStyle/Percent].

### Modifying a format style

Format styles include modifier methods that return a new format style with an adjusted behavior. The following example creates an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle], then applies modifiers to round values down to the nearest 1,000 and applies formatting appropriate to the `fr_FR` locale:

```swift
let style = IntegerFormatStyle<Int>()
    .rounded(rule: .down, increment: 1000)
    .locale(Locale(identifier: "fr_FR"))
let rounded = 123456789.formatted(style) // "123 456 000"
```

Foundation caches identical instances of a customized format style, so you don’t need to pass format style instances around unrelated parts of your app’s source code.

### Accessing static instances

Types that conform to [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] typically extend the base protocol with type properties or type methods to provide convenience instances. These are available for use in a data type’s `formatted(_:)` method when the format style’s input type matches the data type. For example, the various numeric format styles define `number` properties with generic constraints to match the different numeric types ([doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Double], [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int], [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Float16], and so on).

To see how this works, consider this example of a default formatter for an [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int] value. Because `123456789` is a [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger], its [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger/formatted(_:)-4qd73] method accepts an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] parameter. The following example shows the style’s default behavior in the `en_US` locale.

```swift
let formatted = 123456789.formatted(IntegerFormatStyle()) // "123,456,789"
```

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] extends [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] with multiple type properties called `number`, each of which is an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle] instance; these properties differ by which [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryInteger]-conforming type they take as input. Since one of these statically-defined properties ([doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle/number-7fxvo]) takes [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Int] as its input, you can use this type property instead of instantiating a new format style instance. Using dot notation to access this property on the inferred [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FormatStyle] makes the call point much easier to read, as seen here:

```swift
let formatted = 123456789.formatted( .number) // "123,456,789"
```

Furthermore, since you can customize these statically-accessed format style instances, you can rewrite the example from the previous section without instantiating a new [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/IntegerFormatStyle], like this:

```swift
let rounded = 123456789.formatted( .number
    .rounded(rule: .down, increment: 1000)
    .locale(Locale(identifier: "fr_FR"))) // "123 456 000"
```

### Parsing with a format style

To perform the opposite conversion — from formatted output type to input data type — some format styles provide a corresponding [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ParseStrategy] type. These format styles typically expose an instance of this type as a variable, called `parseStrategy`.

You can use a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ParseStrategy] one of two ways:

- Initialize the data type by calling an initializer of that type that takes a formatted instance and a parse strategy as parameters. For example, you can create a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal] from a formatted string with the initializer [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Decimal/init(_:format:lenient:)-6fk71].
- Create a parse strategy and call its [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/ParseStrategy/parse(_:)] method on one or more formatted instances.

## Performing formatting

- **format(_:)**: Formats a value, using this style.

## Setting style Locale

- **locale(_:)**: Modifies the format style to use the specified locale.

## Applying numeric styles for integers

- **number**: A style for formatting the Swift default integer type.
- **number**: A style for formatting the Swift unsigned integer type.
- **number**: A style for formatting 8-bit signed integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 16-bit signed integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 32-bit signed integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 64-bit signed integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 8-bit unsigned integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 16-bit unsigned integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 32-bit unsigned integers.
- **number**: A style for formatting 64-bit unsigned integers.
- **IntegerFormatStyle**: A structure that converts between integer values and their textual representations.

## Applying numeric styles for floating-point values

- **number**: A style for formatting the Swift standard single-precision floating-point type.
- **number**: A style for formatting the Swift standard double-precision floating-point type.
- **number**: A style for formatting 16-bit floating-point values.
- **FloatingPointFormatStyle**: A structure that converts between floating-point values and their textual representations.

## Applying numeric styles for decimals

- **number**: A style for formatting decimal values.
- **Decimal.FormatStyle**: A structure that converts between decimal values and their textual representations.

## Applying percentage styles for integers

- **percent**: A style for formatting signed integer types in Swift as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting signed integer types in Swift as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 8-bit signed integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 16-bit signed integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 32-bit signed integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 64-bit signed integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 8-bit unsigned integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 16-bit unsigned integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 32-bit unsigned integers as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 64-bit unsigned integers as a percent representation.
- **IntegerFormatStyle.Percent**: A format style that converts between integer percentage values and their textual representations.

## Applying percentage styles for floating-point values

- **percent**: A style for formatting the Swift standard single-precision floating-point type as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting the Swift standard single-precision floating-point type as a percent representation.
- **percent**: A style for formatting 16-bit floating-point values as a percent representation.
- **FloatingPointFormatStyle.Percent**: A format style that converts between floating-point percentage values and their textual representations.

## Applying percentage styles for decimals

- **percent**: A style for formatting decimal values as a percent represntation.
- **Decimal.FormatStyle.Percent**: A format style that converts between decimal percentage values and their textual representations.

## Applying date and time styles

- **dateTime**: A style for formatting a date and time.
- **Date.FormatStyle**: A structure that creates a locale-appropriate string representation of a date instance and converts strings of dates and times into date instances.
- **Date.ISO8601FormatStyle**: A type that converts between dates and their ISO-8601 string representations.
- **verbatim(_:locale:timeZone:calendar:)**: Returns a style for formatting a date with an explicitly-specified style.
- **Date.VerbatimFormatStyle**: A style that formats a date with an explicitly-specified style.
- **interval**: A style for formatting a date interval.
- **Date.IntervalFormatStyle**: A format style that creates string representations of date intervals.
- **relative(presentation:unitsStyle:)**: Returns a style for formatting a date as relative to the current date.
- **Date.RelativeFormatStyle**: A format style that forms locale-aware string representations of a relative date or time.
- **components(style:fields:)**: Returns a style for formatting a date interval in terms of specific date components.
- **Date.ComponentsFormatStyle**: A style for formatting a date interval in terms of specific date components.

## Applying duration styles

- **timeDuration**: A style for formatting a duration expressed as a range of dates.
- **Date.ComponentsFormatStyle**: A style for formatting a date interval in terms of specific date components.
- **time(pattern:)**: Returns a style for formatting a duration using a provided pattern.
- **units(allowed:width:maximumUnitCount:zeroValueUnits:valueLength:fractionalPart:)**: Returns a style for formatting a duration that uses the specified units.
- **units(allowed:width:maximumUnitCount:zeroValueUnits:valueLengthLimits:fractionalPart:)**: Returns a style for formatting a duration range that uses the specified units, with padding/truncating behavior defined as a range.

## Applying currency styles

- **currency(code:)**: Returns a format style to use integer currency notation.
- **currency(code:)**: Returns a format style to use floating-point currency notation.
- **currency(code:)**: Returns a format style to use decimal currency notation.

## Applying measurement styles

- **measurement(width:usage:numberFormatStyle:)**: Returns a format style to format measurement units.
- **measurement(width:usage:hidesScaleName:numberFormatStyle:)**: Returns a format style to format temperature units.

## Applying person name styles

- **name(style:)**: Returns a format style to use the given name style for formatting a name from its components.

## Applying list styles

- **list(memberStyle:type:width:)**: Returns a format style to format a list of items.
- **list(type:width:)**: Returns a format style to format a list of strings.

## Applying byte-count styles

- **byteCount(style:allowedUnits:spellsOutZero:includesActualByteCount:)**: Returns a format style to format a data storage value.
- **ByteCountFormatStyle**: A format style that provides string representations of byte counts.
- **byteCount(style:allowedUnits:spellsOutZero:includesActualByteCount:)**: Returns a format style to format a data storage value represented with Foundation’s measurement type.
- **Measurement.FormatStyle.ByteCount**: A format style that provides string representations of byte counts, expressed as measurements of information storage.

## Applying URL styles

- **url**: A style for formatting a URL.
- **URL.FormatStyle**: A structure that converts between URL instances and their textual representations.

## Declaring input and output types

- **FormatInput**: The type this format style accepts as input.
- **FormatOutput**: The type this format style produces as output.

## Type Properties

- **http**
- **http**
- **iso8601**
- **iso8601**

## Type Methods

- **offset(to:allowedFields:maxFieldCount:sign:)**
- **reference(to:allowedFields:maxFieldCount:thresholdField:)**
- **stopwatch(startingAt:showsHours:maxFieldCount:maxPrecision:)**
- **timer(countingDownIn:showsHours:maxFieldCount:maxPrecision:)**
- **timer(countingUpIn:showsHours:maxFieldCount:maxPrecision:)**

## Data formatting in Swift

- **Language Introspector**: Converts data into human-readable text using formatters and locales.
- **IntegerFormatStyle**: A structure that converts between integer values and their textual representations.
- **FloatingPointFormatStyle**: A structure that converts between floating-point values and their textual representations.
- **Decimal.FormatStyle**: A structure that converts between decimal values and their textual representations.
- **ListFormatStyle**: A type that formats lists of items with a separator and conjunction appropriate for a given locale.
- **StringStyle**
- **URL.FormatStyle**: A structure that converts between URL instances and their textual representations.
- **FormatStyleCapitalizationContext**: The capitalization formatting context used when formatting dates and times.
- **Format Style Configurations**: Behaviors for traits like numeric precision, rounding, and scale, used for formatting and parsing numeric values.

## Inherits From

- Decodable
- Encodable
- Equatable
- Hashable

## Inherited By

- DiscreteFormatStyle
- ParseableFormatStyle

## Conforming Types

- ByteCountFormatStyle
- ByteCountFormatStyle.Attributed
- Date.AnchoredRelativeFormatStyle
- Date.AttributedStyle
- Date.ComponentsFormatStyle
- Date.FormatStyle
- Date.FormatStyle.Attributed
- Date.HTTPFormatStyle
- Date.ISO8601FormatStyle
- Date.IntervalFormatStyle
- Date.RelativeFormatStyle
- Date.VerbatimFormatStyle
- Date.VerbatimFormatStyle.Attributed
- DateComponents.HTTPFormatStyle
- DateComponents.ISO8601FormatStyle
- Decimal.FormatStyle
- Decimal.FormatStyle.Attributed
- Decimal.FormatStyle.Currency
- Decimal.FormatStyle.Percent
- FloatingPointFormatStyle
- FloatingPointFormatStyle.Attributed
- FloatingPointFormatStyle.Currency
- FloatingPointFormatStyle.Percent
- IntegerFormatStyle
- IntegerFormatStyle.Attributed
- IntegerFormatStyle.Currency
- IntegerFormatStyle.Percent
- ListFormatStyle
- Measurement.AttributedStyle
- Measurement.AttributedStyle.ByteCount
- Measurement.FormatStyle
- Measurement.FormatStyle.ByteCount
- PersonNameComponents.AttributedStyle
- PersonNameComponents.FormatStyle
- StringStyle
- URL.FormatStyle

title: FormatStyle
